senses.definition: the process of helping something/somebody to make progress or succeed; the progress that is made

examples.x: the advancement of knowledge/education/science
advancements in science

senses.definition: progress in a job, social class, etc.

examples.x: There are good opportunities for advancement if you have the right skills.

senses.definition: to examine the nature or structure of something, especially by separating it into its parts, in order to understand or explain it examine

examples.x: The job involves collecting and analysing data.
Researchers have analysed the results in detail using specialist software.
Learn to step back and critically analyse situations.
He tried to analyse his feelings.
The first step is to define and analyse the problem.
The water samples will be analysed for the presence of polluting chemicals.
We need to analyse what went wrong.

senses.definition: to treat or study somebody using psychoanalysis
the detailed study or examination of something in order to understand more about it; the result of the study

examples.x: statistical/data analysis
a detailed analysis of the data
to perform/conduct an analysis
Further analysis revealed significant regional variations in the results.
We made the decision based on our analysis of the situation.
to be included in/excluded from the analysis

senses.definition: a careful examination of a substance in order to find out what it consists of

examples.x: The blood samples are sent to the laboratory for analysis.
the results of a DNA sequence analysis
You can ask for a chemical analysis of your tap water.

senses.definition: a method of treating somebody who has problems with their mental health by asking them to talk about past experiences and feelings, and trying to help them understand fears and feelings that they were not conscious of

examples.x: In analysis the individual resolves difficult emotional conflicts.

senses.definition: the scientific study of the physical structure of humans, animals or plants

examples.x: the department of anatomy and physiology

senses.definition: the physical structure of a human, animal or plant

examples.x: the anatomy of the horse
human anatomy

senses.definition: a person’s body

examples.x: Various parts of his anatomy were clearly visible.

senses.definition: an examination of what something is like or why it happens

examples.x: an anatomy of the current recession

senses.definition: the tools or other pieces of equipment that are needed for a particular activity or task equipment

examples.x: a piece of laboratory apparatus
Firefighters needed breathing apparatus to enter the burning house.
Science departments say they are lacking basic apparatus.

senses.definition: the structure of a system or an organization, particularly that of a political party or a government

examples.x: the power of the state apparatus
We cannot do without the apparatus of government in protecting the rights of the individual.

senses.definition: a system of organs in the body

examples.x: the sensory apparatus

senses.definition: the study of cultures of the past, and of periods of history by examining the parts of buildings and objects found in the ground
a cup, usually made of plastic and often without a handle, used for drinking from

examples.x: She drank from a plastic beaker.

senses.definition: the amount contained in a beaker

examples.x: a beaker of coffee

senses.definition: a glass cup with straight sides and a lip, used in chemistry, for example for measuring liquids

examples.x: a glass beaker containing copper sulphate solution

senses.definition: a strong feeling in favour of or against one group of people, or one side in an argument, often not based on fair judgement fight for/​struggle for/​promote

examples.x: accusations of political bias in news programmes (= that reports are unfair and show favour to one political party)
Employers must consider all candidates impartially and without bias.
Do you think that there's still a bias against women in some industries?
The article examines gender bias in our schools.

senses.definition: an interest in one thing more than others; a special ability

examples.x: The course has a strong practical bias.
Leila had a marked scientific bias.
In some British universities there was a bias towards pure science.

senses.definition: the fact that the results of research or an experiment are not accurate because a particular factor has not been considered when collecting the information

examples.x: If a response rate is low, the risk of bias in the findings will be greater.

senses.definition: the bias of a piece of cloth is an edge cut diagonally across the threads bias

examples.x: The skirt is cut on the bias.
a bias strip

senses.definition: to unfairly influence somebody’s opinions or decisions

examples.x: The newspapers have biased people against her.
The report suggests that television reporting is biased towards the government in power.

senses.definition: to have an effect on the results of research or an experiment so that they do not show the real situation

examples.x: The experiment contained an error which could bias the results.
These errors may bias the statistics.
The sequence of questions may bias the answers.
Their methodology resulted in biased findings.

senses.definition: the scientific study of the chemistry of living things
the chemical structure and behaviour of a living thing

examples.x: Your biochemistry is almost identical to that of your cat.

senses.definition: the scientific study of the life and structure of plants and animals

examples.x: a degree in biology
molecular/evolutionary biology
a biology teacher/class/textbook
She's a professor of biology at Stanford.

senses.definition: the way in which the body and cells of a living thing behave

examples.x: How far is human nature determined by biology?
the biology of marine animals

senses.definition: a scientist who studies botany
the scientific study of plants and their structure -y
an instrument used in scientific work that produces a hot gas flame
a method of calculating the age of very old objects by measuring the amounts of different forms of carbon in them
a detailed account of the development of a person, a group of people or a situation over a period of time

examples.x: She co-authored a case study on urban development.

senses.definition: a person, group of people, situation, etc. that is used to study a particular idea or theory

examples.x: Athletes make an interesting case study for doctors.

senses.definition: the scientific study of the structure of substances, how they react when combined or in contact with one another, and how they behave under different conditions

examples.x: a degree in chemistry
He did physics and chemistry at university.
the university’s chemistry department
inorganic/organic chemistry

senses.definition: the chemical structure and behaviour of a particular substance

examples.x: the chemistry of copper
We do not fully understand the chemistry of genes.
The patient's blood chemistry was monitored regularly.
natural changes in body chemistry

senses.definition: the relationship between two people, usually a strong sexual attraction

examples.x: sexual chemistry
The chemistry just wasn't right.
The personal chemistry between the two stars is obvious.

senses.definition: a box of equipment that children can use to perform simple chemistry experiments

examples.x: Back in the day, you could buy a chemistry set that had real chemicals.

senses.definition: to arrange something in groups according to features that they have in common

examples.x: The books in the library are classified according to subject.
Patients are classified into three categories.
These can be classified under five headings.
We can classify machines in terms of their function.

senses.definition: to decide which type or group somebody/something belongs to

examples.x: Only eleven of these accidents were classified as major.
It was classified as a sports car, which meant a $3 000 annual insurance bill.

senses.definition: to state that information is officially secret

examples.x: All the documents relating to the case have been classified.

senses.definition: the scientific study of climate
a research study in which a medical treatment is carefully tested on people in order to assess how safe and effective it is

examples.x: The new drug is undergoing clinical trials.

senses.definition: if two ideas, facts, etc. colligate, or are colligated, they are linked together by a single explanation or theory colligate
if two words colligate, or are colligated, they occur together and are linked by grammar colligate
to decide or believe something as a result of what you have heard or seen In conclusion

examples.x: It is too early for us to conclude anything.
What do you conclude from that?
The report concluded (that) the cheapest option was to close the laboratory.
He concluded from their remarks that they were not in favour of the plan.
It was concluded that the level of change necessary would be low.
‘So it should be safe to continue,’ he concluded.

senses.definition: to come to an end; to bring something to an end

examples.x: This was how the negotiations finally concluded.
Let me make just a few concluding remarks.
the concluding chapter of the book
The programme concluded with Stravinsky's ‘Rite of Spring’.
He concluded by wishing everyone a safe trip home.
The commission concluded its investigation last month.
And that concludes our programme for today.
The main responsibility of a salesperson is to conclude a sale successfully.
She concluded her speech with a quotation from Shakespeare.
‘Anyway, she should be back soon,’ he concluded.

senses.definition: to arrange and settle an agreement with somebody formally and finally

examples.x: They concluded a treaty with Turkey.
A trade agreement was concluded between the two countries.
The problems arose from the failure to conclude a new agreement.

senses.definition: something that you decide when you have thought about all the information connected with the situation formulate/​advance

examples.x: We can safely draw some conclusions from our discussion.
He arrived at a different conclusion.
There is abundant evidence to support this conclusion.
Other studies have yielded the same conclusion.
The final section summarizes the conclusions of the study.
I've come to the conclusion that he's not the right person for the job.
New evidence might lead to the conclusion that we are wrong.
It is too soon to reach any conclusions about voting trends.

senses.definition: the end of something such as a speech or a piece of writing In conclusion

examples.x: The conclusion of the book was disappointing.
After his death, his assistant completed chapters nine and ten and wrote the conclusion.
If we took this argument to its logical conclusion…
The film is a fitting conclusion to the series.
In conclusion (= finally), I would like to thank…

senses.definition: the formal and final arrangement of something official

examples.x: the successful conclusion of a trade treaty

senses.definition: to organize and/or do a particular activity

examples.x: to conduct an experiment/inquiry/investigation/interview
to conduct a survey/poll/study/review
to conduct a test/trial
to conduct research/business
There are concerns about the way in which the firm conducts its activities.
The battalion had been preparing to conduct operations in the same area.
Police conducted a thorough search of the building.
The negotiations have been conducted in a positive manner.
They conducted a vigorous campaign for a shorter working week.

senses.definition: to direct a group of people who are singing or playing music

examples.x: a concert by the London Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Marin Alsop
He conducted a programme of Sibelius and Tchaikovsky.
He will conduct works by Brahms and Schumann in tonight's concert.
She sang Gluck's Orfeo at Covent Garden, with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting.

senses.definition: to lead or guide somebody through or around a place

examples.x: a conducted tour of Athens (= one with a guide, giving information about it)
The guide conducted us around the ruins of the ancient city.

senses.definition: to behave in a particular way

examples.x: He conducted himself far better than expected.
The report challenges them to examine how they conduct themselves in the workplace.

senses.definition: to allow heat or electricity to pass along or through it

examples.x: Copper conducts electricity well.

senses.definition: to state or show that something is definitely true or correct, especially by providing evidence

examples.x: His guilty expression confirmed my suspicions.
to confirm a diagnosis/report
to confirm results/findings
Rumours of job losses were later confirmed.
We have yet to confirm the identities of the victims.
She said she could not confirm or deny the allegations.
The authorities refused to confirm any details.
Police sources confirmed that ten people had been arrested at the march.
A government official confirmed to the newspaper that Britain was pushing hard for an end to the arms embargo.
Can you confirm what happened?
It has been confirmed that an official complaint was made to the council.

senses.definition: to make a position, an agreement, etc. more definite or official; to establish somebody/something clearly

examples.x: Please write to confirm your reservation (= say that it is definite).
After a six-month probationary period, her position was confirmed.
Has everyone confirmed (that) they’re coming?
It has been confirmed that the meeting will take place next week.
He was confirmed as captain for the rest of the season.
I'm very happy to confirm you in your post.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel or believe something even more strongly

examples.x: The walk in the mountains confirmed his fear of heights.
This latest tragedy merely confirms my view that the law must be tightened.

senses.definition: to perform the Christian or Jewish ceremony of confirmation

examples.x: She was baptized when she was a month old and confirmed when she was thirteen.

senses.definition: a number or quantity that does not vary

examples.x: fundamental physical constants

senses.definition: the power to make decisions about how a country, an area, an organization, etc. is run

examples.x: The party expects to gain control of the council in the next election.
Militants have taken control of the town.
The Democrats have lost control of Congress.
A military junta seized control of the country.
The founders eventually regained control of the company.
He defended the tradition of civilian control over the military.
The city is in the control of enemy forces.
The area remains under international control.

senses.definition: the ability to make somebody/something do what you want

examples.x: The teacher had no control over the children.
He fought hard to retain control over his work.
She struggled to keep control of her voice.
She lost control of her car on the ice.
He got so angry he lost control (= shouted and said or did things he would not normally do).
Owing to circumstances beyond our control, the flight to Rome has been cancelled.
The situation is under control.
The coach made the team work hard on ball control (= in a ball game).

senses.definition: the act of limiting or managing something; a method of doing this limit

examples.x: traffic control
talks on arms control
tight controls on government spending
Price controls on food were ended.
exciting advances in the control of malaria
state control of the economy
It was an exercise in damage control (= trying to prevent further damage).
A pest control officer was called in to deal with the rat problem.

senses.definition: the switches and buttons, etc. that you use to operate a machine or a vehicle

examples.x: the controls of an aircraft
the control panel
the volume control of a TV
The co-pilot was at the controls when the plane landed.

senses.definition: a person, thing or group used as a standard of comparison for checking the results of a scientific experiment; an experiment whose result is known, used for checking working methods

examples.x: The study showed that women with the disease have had fewer children than the controls.
One group was treated with the new drug, and the control group was given a sugar pill.

senses.definition: a place where orders are given or where checks are made; the people who work in this place

examples.x: We went through passport control and into the departure lounge.

senses.definition: (on a computer keyboard) a key that you press when you want to perform a particular operation
a scientific experiment in which only one condition is changed in each of several tests in order to find out what effect that condition has on the results of the experiment

examples.x: Controlled experiments show how shore crabs of different sizes respond to ship noise.

senses.definition: if two or more facts, figures, etc. correlate or if a fact, figure, etc. correlates with another, the facts are closely connected and affect or depend on each other correlate

examples.x: The figures do not seem to correlate.
A high-fat diet correlates with a greater risk of heart disease.
The average speed of the vehicles correlates closely with the severity of the accident caused.

senses.definition: to show that there is a close connection between two or more facts, figures, etc.

examples.x: Researchers are trying to correlate the two sets of figures.
Property values are negatively correlated to the tax rate.

senses.definition: a connection between two things in which one thing changes as the other does

examples.x: There is a direct correlation between exposure to sun and skin cancer.
the correlation of social power with wealth

senses.definition: to provide evidence or information that supports a statement, theory, etc. Corroborate

examples.x: The evidence was corroborated by two independent witnesses.
corroborating evidence

senses.definition: evidence or information that supports a statement, theory, etc.

examples.x: The prosecution provided corroboration for her allegation.

senses.definition: the scientific study of communication and control systems, which involves comparing human and animal brains with machines and electronic devices
facts or information, especially when examined and used to find out things or to make decisions formulate/​advance

examples.x: We collected publicly available data over a 10-day period.
to gather/obtain data
What methods are you using to interpret the data?
Researchers analysed the data on 2 515 patient visits at the Children's Hospital.
Table 2 provides data for south-east Nebraska.
Our model is based on experimental data.
published/unpublished data
scientific/historical/clinical data
It is essential to protect your personal data.
raw data (= that has not been analysed)
Multiple data collection methods were used.
These data show that most cancers are detected as a result of clinical follow-up.

senses.definition: information that is stored by a computer

examples.x: All this data is stored on hundreds of servers in San Francisco.
data storage/transfer

senses.definition: to pull or knock down a building; to destroy something

examples.x: The factory is due to be demolished next year.
The old slums are being demolished to make way for a new housing project.
The car had skidded across the road and demolished part of the wall.
Tornadoes demolished trailers and blew roofs off houses.

senses.definition: to show that an idea or theory is completely wrong

examples.x: A recent book has demolished this theory.
He has successfully demolished the opposition's arguments.

senses.definition: to defeat somebody easily and completely

examples.x: They demolished New Zealand 44–6 in the final.

senses.definition: to eat something very quickly

examples.x: The children demolished their burgers and chips.

senses.definition: to discover or notice something, especially something that is not easy to see, hear, etc. notice

examples.x: The tests are designed to detect the disease early.
Only 8 per cent of regular cola consumers detected a difference.
The sensor detects changes in light level and temperature.
a test that can detect the presence of calcium in the arteries
This is an instrument that can detect very small amounts of radiation.
Do I detect a note of criticism?

senses.definition: that can be discovered or noticed

examples.x: The noise is barely detectable by the human ear.

senses.definition: to discover the facts about something; to calculate something exactly

examples.x: An inquiry was set up to determine the cause of the accident.
Try to determine the extent of the problem.
We set out to determine exactly what happened that night.
It is difficult to determine when drama first appeared in India.
It was determined that she had died of natural causes.

senses.definition: to make something happen in a particular way or be of a particular type

examples.x: Rural voters in key states will determine the outcome of the election.
Upbringing plays an important part in determining a person's character.
Age and experience will be determining factors in our choice of candidate.
The physical capabilities of a plant determine where it can and cannot live.

senses.definition: to officially decide and/or arrange something

examples.x: A date for the meeting has yet to be determined.
The court determined (that) the defendant should pay the legal costs.

senses.definition: to decide definitely to do something

examples.x: They determined to start early.
The government determined on a change of policy.
From that moment, I determined that it should not happen again.

senses.definition: to gradually grow or become bigger, more advanced, stronger, etc.; to make something do this

examples.x: From birth to age 5, a child's brain develops rapidly.
Some children develop more slowly than others.
Gradually these settlements developed into cities.
Human beings developed from earlier species of animals.
The place has rapidly developed from a small fishing community into a thriving tourist resort.
The aim is to develop your personal skills.
She developed the company from nothing.
The competition helps entrants develop ideas into business concepts.

senses.definition: to start to have a skill, ability, quality, etc. that becomes better and stronger; to become better and stronger

examples.x: He's developed a real flair for management.
Their relationship has developed over a number of years.

senses.definition: to think of or produce a new idea, product, etc. and make it successful make

examples.x: The company develops and markets new software.
It takes time to develop new technology.
We are developing products for different parts of the industry.
to develop a strategy/system/programme
to develop a method/model/technique
A new type of painkilling drug has recently been developed.

senses.definition: to begin to have something such as a disease or a problem; to start to affect somebody/something

examples.x: She developed lung cancer at the age of sixty.
Her son developed asthma when he was two.
The car developed engine trouble and we had to stop.
If symptoms develop, seek help quickly.
Problems can develop unexpectedly.

senses.definition: to start to happen or change, especially in a bad way

examples.x: A crisis was rapidly developing in the Gulf.
We need more time to see how things develop before we take action.
The conflict quickly developed into full-scale war.
The situation is developing into a crisis.

senses.definition: to build new houses, factories, etc. on an area of land, especially land that was not being used effectively before

examples.x: The site is being developed by a French company.

senses.definition: to build or improve a building or other facilities

examples.x: The company is developing a chain of hotels.
He is enthusiastic about plans to develop the leisure facilities at the site.

senses.definition: to become economically and socially more advanced

examples.x: For a country to develop, a good road network is essential.
Their economy was developing at an incredible pace.

senses.definition: to add further explanation or details to an idea, story or musical theme

examples.x: She develops the theme more fully in her later books.
The piano then takes up the melody and develops it.
He began to develop these ideas in a series of paintings.

senses.definition: to treat film that has been used to take photographs with chemicals so that the pictures can be seen

examples.x: When Lewis developed the film, he was astonished by what he saw.

senses.definition: the steady growth of something so that it becomes more advanced, stronger, etc.

examples.x: a baby’s development in the womb
This is a perfectly normal stage of development.
the development of basic skills such as literacy and numeracy
The company can offer a number of opportunities for career development.

senses.definition: the growth of the economy of a country or region through increased business activity

examples.x: Increased tourism will promote job creation and economic development.
International policies should support, not inhibit, sustainable development.
He described women as the backbone of rural development worldwide.
community development projects
a development plan/programme

senses.definition: the process of producing or creating something new or more advanced; a new or advanced product or idea

examples.x: the development of new technology
Pete is head of product development.
A more powerful version of this electric bus is currently in development.
A new vaccine is under development.
This drug is an exciting new development.
developments in aviation technology

senses.definition: a new event or stage that is likely to affect what happens in a continuing situation

examples.x: Have there been any further developments?
We welcome the recent positive developments.
the latest developments in the war
There have been some interesting new developments in the case.

senses.definition: a piece of land with new buildings on it

examples.x: I live in a brand-new housing development.
a mixed residential and business development

senses.definition: the process of using an area of land, especially to make a profit by building on it, etc.

examples.x: He bought the land for development.
The city has undergone rapid development.

senses.definition: to be the first person to become aware that a particular place or thing exists

examples.x: Cook is credited with discovering Hawaii.
Scientists around the world are working to discover a cure for the disease.
a newly discovered snake species
They first discovered this protein about five years ago.
She recently discovered two fungi that were new to science.

senses.definition: to find somebody/something that was hidden or that you did not expect to find

examples.x: Police discovered a large stash of drugs while searching the house.
We discovered this beach while we were sailing around the island.
His body was discovered in the lake near his house.
He was discovered hiding in a shed.
She was discovered dead at her home in Leeds.

senses.definition: to find out about something; to find some information about something

examples.x: She was determined to discover the truth about her neighbours.
to discover a secret
I've just discovered hang-gliding!
Discover the joys of yoga!
It was a shock to discover (that) he couldn’t read.
We never did discover why she gave up her job.
It was later discovered that the diaries were a fraud.
He was later discovered to be seriously ill.

senses.definition: to be the first person to realize that somebody is very good at singing, acting, etc. and help them to become successful and famous

examples.x: The singer was discovered while still at school.
There's great talent out there just waiting to be discovered.

senses.definition: an act or the process of finding somebody/something, or learning about something that was not known about before

examples.x: Researchers in this field have made some important new discoveries.
New scientific discoveries are being made all the time.
the discovery of antibiotics in the twentieth century
The discovery of a child's body in the river has shocked the community.
the discovery of new talent in the art world
He saw life as a voyage of discovery.
The film takes us on a journey of discovery to different parts of the globe.
She was shocked by the discovery that he had been unfaithful.
In 1974 Hawking made the discovery (= he discovered) that black holes give off radiation.

senses.definition: a thing, fact or person that is found or learned about for the first time

examples.x: The drug is not a new discovery—it's been known about for years.
one of the most important scientific discoveries of all time
potentially the biggest archaeological discovery in Norway for fifty years
recent discoveries about sleep

senses.definition: to show that something is wrong or false Disprove

examples.x: The theory has now been disproved.

senses.definition: to cut up a dead person, animal or plant in order to study it

examples.x: The biology students had to dissect a rat.
dissecting instruments

senses.definition: to study something closely and/or discuss it in great detail

examples.x: Her latest novel was dissected by the critics.

senses.definition: to divide something into smaller pieces, areas, etc.

examples.x: The city is dissected by a network of old canals.

senses.definition: a science that involves studying the earth or part of it. Geography and geology are both earth sciences.
an expert in earth science

examples.x: Earth scientists have long known that earthquakes can trigger volcanic eruptions.

senses.definition: based on experiments or experience rather than ideas or theories Empirical

examples.x: empirical evidence/knowledge/research
an empirical study

senses.definition: in a way that is based on experiments or experience rather than ideas or theories

examples.x: Such claims need to be tested empirically.

senses.definition: the activity of applying scientific knowledge to the design, building and control of machines, roads, bridges, electrical equipment, etc.

examples.x: The bridge is a triumph of modern engineering.
an engineering firm/company
Train services on Sunday will be restricted because of engineering works.

senses.definition: the study of engineering as a subject

examples.x: a degree in engineering
an engineering student

senses.definition: the things that are needed for a particular purpose or activity equipment

examples.x: a useful piece of equipment for the kitchen
Take care when using old electrical equipment.
electronic/communications/computer equipment
military equipment and supplies
office equipment
They have installed state-of-the-art medical equipment to help improve early diagnosis of the condition.
Everyone should bring the necessary equipment for camping in the mountains.

senses.definition: the process of providing a place or person with necessary things

examples.x: The equipment of the photographic studio was expensive.

senses.definition: to form an opinion of the amount, value or quality of something after thinking about it carefully

examples.x: The trial will evaluate the effectiveness of the different drugs.
Researchers evaluated teaching performance by comparing students' exam results.
The study will critically evaluate whether this technology is useful.
We need to evaluate how well the policy is working.
The cheeses are evaluated for flavour, texture and colour.
Candidates are evaluated on their ability to think independently.

senses.definition: the act of forming an opinion of the amount, value or quality of something after thinking about it carefully

examples.x: an evaluation of the healthcare system
The technique is not widely practised and requires further evaluation.
The discussion includes a critical evaluation of the documentary sources.

senses.definition: the facts, signs or objects that make you believe that something is true evidence

examples.x: Researchers have found clear scientific evidence of a link between exposure to sun and skin cancer.
There is a growing body of evidence for the existence of black holes that are ten times as massive as the Sun.
There is not a shred of evidence that the meeting actually took place.

examples.cf: evidence to suggest, support, show, etc.
examples.x: Have you any evidence to support this allegation?
The study provides empirical evidence (= based on experiments or experience) to prove that the drug has no long-term side effects.
Anecdotal evidence (= based on personal accounts) suggests that drivers over the age of 70 find it difficult to get insurance.
On the evidence of their recent matches, it is unlikely the Spanish team will win.
In the absence of evidence to the contrary, it should be assumed that proper procedures were followed.

senses.definition: the information that is used in court to try to prove something break/​violate/​obey/​uphold

examples.x: I was asked to give evidence (= to say what I knew, describe what I had seen, etc.) at the trial.
The defence accused the prosecution of withholding several key pieces of evidence.
circumstantial/forensic evidence
Despite a lack of evidence against him, Burton will appear in court next week.
He was released when the judge ruled there was no evidence against him.
The emails were presented as evidence of his involvement in the fraud.
The police officer took a statement which was later used in evidence.

senses.definition: used to describe an approach that is based on the practical application of research findings

examples.x: The planners considered it important to implement an evidence-based approach to the problem of traffic congestion.
In medical school, we were taught to practise evidence-based medicine.

senses.definition: to do a scientific experiment or experiments

examples.x: After experimenting at Columbia University, he realized that fission was the key to releasing nuclear energy.
Some people feel that experimenting on animals is wrong.
They experimented successfully on the plants to discover disease-resistant varieties.
The country had secretly experimented with biological weapons for years.

senses.definition: to try or test new ideas, methods, etc. to find out what effect they have

examples.x: I experimented until I got the recipe just right.
She had experimented with drugs when she was at college.
He wanted to experiment more with different textures in his paintings.

senses.definition: based on new ideas, forms or methods that are used to find out what effect they have

examples.x: The school's experimental teaching methods include letting the children decide what to study.
experimental theatre/art/music
The equipment is still at the experimental stage.
Doctors stress that this kind of treatment is still experimental.

senses.definition: connected with scientific experiments

examples.x: experimental conditions/data/evidence
experimental physics

senses.definition: the activity or process of doing scientific experiments Experimentation

examples.x: Further experimentation is needed to verify this hypothesis.
Many people object to experimentation on embryos.

senses.definition: the activity or process of trying or testing new ideas, methods, etc. to find out what effect they have

examples.x: He has a flair for musical experimentation.
experimentation with new teaching methods

senses.definition: a thing that is known to be true, especially when it can be proved

examples.x: First, some basic facts about healthy eating.
Isn't it a fact that the firm is losing money?
It's a well-known fact that dogs have an acute sense of smell.
I know for a fact (= I am certain) that she's involved in something illegal.
The report is based on hard facts (= information that can be proved to be true).
Get your facts right (= make sure your information is correct) before you start making accusations.
It's about time you learnt to face (the) facts (= accepted the truth about the situation).
We didn't get on well, and that's a fact.
The judge instructed both lawyers to stick to the facts of the case.

senses.definition: things that are true rather than things that have been invented

examples.x: The story is based on fact.
Is the account fact or fiction?
This is simply historical fact.
It's important to distinguish between fact and opinion.

senses.definition: used to refer to a particular situation that exists however

examples.x: I could no longer ignore the fact that he was unhappy.
We don't hide the fact that we've made mistakes.
I did everything I could, and she acknowledged the fact.
Students are already highly media-literate and the curriculum needs to reflect this fact.
The very fact that this happened more than once shows there is a problem.
Despite the fact that she was wearing a seat belt, she was thrown sharply forward.
Due to the fact that they did not read English, the prisoners were unaware of what they were signing.
She was happy apart from the fact that she could not return home.

examples.cf: in view of the fact that…
examples.x: Voluntary work was particularly important in view of the fact that women were often forced to give up paid work on marriage.
We want to celebrate the simple fact of their being here.
The mere fact of being poor can put children at an educational disadvantage.
The fact remains that we are still two teachers short.

senses.definition: the act of changing a written record or information so that it is no longer true

examples.x: the deliberate falsification of the company’s records

senses.definition: to change a written record or information so that it is no longer true

examples.x: to falsify data/records/accounts
She was arrested for falsifying information and obstructing the course of justice.

senses.definition: a device containing paper, sand, chemicals, etc. that a liquid or gas is passed through in order to remove any materials that are not wanted

examples.x: an air/oil filter
a coffee/water filter
filter paper for the coffee machine

senses.definition: a device that allows only particular types of light or sound to pass through it

examples.x: The camera has an anti-glare filter.

senses.definition: a program that processes information to leave out the types that are not wanted, or that stops particular types of electronic information, email, etc. from being sent to a computer

examples.x: When you do a search, there are filters for size and brand.
Spam filters block out almost all threats.

senses.definition: a tool on digital cameras, photo apps, etc. that allows you to change the appearance of an image

examples.x: The software allows you to apply filters, remove blemishes and add text to your images.

senses.definition: a light on a set of traffic lights showing that traffic can turn left (or right) while traffic that wants to go straight ahead or turn right (or left) must wait

examples.x: a filter lane

senses.definition: information that is discovered as the result of research into something formulate/​advance

examples.x: Our research findings indicate that pregnant women benefit from this treatment.
These findings suggest that there is no direct link between unemployment and crime.
This result confirms the findings of many previous studies.
to report/present/publish your findings
I'll now summarize the key findings from these studies.
An interesting finding of the survey was that older people were happier than younger people.

senses.definition: a decision made by the judge or jury in a court case

examples.x: The appeal court upheld a finding that the agreement was unlawful.
The court made a finding in favour of the defendant.

senses.definition: a bottle with a narrow top, used in scientific work for mixing or storing chemicals

examples.x: a culture flask containing 4 ml of the medium
Heat the solution gently in a conical flask.

senses.definition: a container like a bottle with double walls with a vacuum between them, used for keeping liquids hot or cold

examples.x: a flask of tea/coffee

senses.definition: a small flat bottle made of metal or glass and often covered with leather, used for carrying alcohol with you

examples.x: He had a flask of Scotch in his pocket.

senses.definition: the scientific study of food, for example what it is made of, the effects it has on our body, and how to prepare it and store it safely
the use of food science in developing, processing or preserving foods

examples.x: Singapore is a world leader in food technology.
She has a degree in Food Technology.

senses.definition: a series of letters, numbers or symbols that represent a rule or law

examples.x: This formula is used to calculate the area of a circle.

senses.definition: letters and symbols that show the parts of a chemical compound, etc.

examples.x: CO is the formula for carbon monoxide.

senses.definition: a particular method of doing or achieving something

examples.x: They're trying to work out a peace formula acceptable to both sides in the dispute.
All the patients were interviewed according to a standard formula.
There's no magic formula for a perfect marriage.
We think we might have hit on a winning formula.

senses.definition: a list of the things that something is made from, giving the amount of each substance to use

examples.x: the secret formula for the blending of the whisky

senses.definition: a type of liquid food for babies, given instead of breast milk
a class of racing car, based on engine size, etc.

examples.x: Formula One™ racing

senses.definition: a fixed form of words used in a particular situation

examples.x: What are the correct legal formulae for this kind of letter?
The minister keeps coming out with the same tired formulas.

senses.definition: a device that is wide at the top and narrow at the bottom, used for pouring liquids or powders into a small opening
a metal chimney, for example on a ship or an engine, through which smoke comes out
connected with the study of the different chemical substances that combine to form the earth and its rocks and minerals

examples.x: geochemical sampling/analysis
a geochemical survey

senses.definition: the study of the different chemical substances that combine to form the earth and its rocks and minerals

examples.x: soil geochemistry

senses.definition: a scientist who studies geology
the scientific study of the physical structure of the earth, including the origin and history of the rocks and soil of which the earth is made
the origin and history of the rocks and soil of a particular area

examples.x: the geology of the British Isles

senses.definition: the sciences concerned with studying the earth or part of it, especially geology

examples.x: a professor of geosciences

senses.definition: a small animal with short ears and no tail, often kept as a pet
a person used in medical or other experiments

examples.x: Students in fifty schools are to act as guinea pigs for these new teaching methods.

senses.definition: the scientific study of the earth’s water, especially its movement in relation to land
an idea or explanation of something that is based on a few known facts but that has not yet been proved to be true or correct formulate/​advance

examples.x: to formulate/confirm a hypothesis
a hypothesis about the function of dreams
There is little evidence to support these hypotheses.

senses.definition: guesses and ideas that are not based on certain knowledge

examples.x: It would be pointless to engage in hypothesis before we have the facts.

senses.definition: an object used for producing musical sounds, for example a piano or a drum

examples.x: to play an instrument
Is he learning an instrument?
percussion/brass/string instruments
an instrument maker

senses.definition: a tool or device used for a particular task, especially for specialist or scientific work

examples.x: surgical/optical/scientific instruments
Scientists then began using powerful instruments to peer through the planet's dense atmosphere.
syringes, needles or other sharp instruments
medieval instruments of torture such as the rack and the wheel
Instruments for diagnosis and surgery have become hugely more sophisticated.
the world's most powerful instrument for detecting gamma rays

senses.definition: a device used for measuring speed, distance, temperature, etc. in a vehicle or on a machine

examples.x: data gathered by instruments aboard the satellite
the flight instruments
There was a warning light flashing on the instrument panel.

senses.definition: something that is used by somebody in order to achieve something; a person or thing that makes something happen

examples.x: The law is not the best instrument for dealing with family matters.
an instrument of change

senses.definition: a person who is used and controlled by somebody/something that is more powerful

examples.x: an instrument of fate
The despot claimed to be the chosen instrument of divine providence.

senses.definition: a formal legal document

examples.x: credit instruments issued by banks

senses.definition: a newspaper or magazine that deals with a particular subject or profession

examples.x: a scientific/an academic journal
the British Medical Journal
the Journal of Experimental Psychology
a trade/professional/specialist journal
an online journal
a journal article
The results of the study are expected to be published in a peer-reviewed journal next month.

senses.definition: used in the title of some newspapers

examples.x: the Wall Street Journal

senses.definition: a written record of the things you do, see, etc. every day

examples.x: He kept a journal of his travels across Asia.
I'm keeping a food journal for a school science project.
Her journal entry for that day describes a thunderstorm.

senses.definition: the scientific study of movement of the body

examples.x: She plans to study either sports medicine or kinesiology.

senses.definition: a laboratory Lab

examples.x: a computer/research lab
the school science labs
She'd been working in the lab all day.
a lab technician
a lab coat (= a white coat worn by scientists, etc. working in a laboratory)

senses.definition: a room or building used for scientific research, experiments, testing, etc.

examples.x: a clinical/research laboratory
to send a specimen to the laboratory for analysis
The effects of weathering can be simulated in the laboratory.
laboratory experiments/tests
The athletes' reflexes were tested under laboratory conditions.

senses.definition: a rule that deals with a particular crime, agreement, etc.

examples.x: to pass a law (= officially make it part of the system of laws)
Police don't have the resources to enforce the law against dumping waste.
There ought to be a law against it!
The company's actions violated the law on equal employment.
The suspects were in clear violation of immigration laws.

senses.definition: the whole system of rules that everyone in a country or society must obey break/​violate/​obey/​uphold

examples.x: If they entered the building they would be breaking the law.
The reforms have recently become law.
The Civil Rights Act of 1964 became the law of the land on July 2, 1964.
state/federal law
State law prohibits gambling in public places.
In Sweden it is against the law to hit a child.
Defence attorneys can use any means within the law to get their client off.
to operate outside the law
British schools are required by law to publish their exam results.
Under existing law, journalists cannot refuse to provide information to a jury.
Do not think you are above the law (= that you cannot be punished by the law).
They acted in accordance with the law of the country.
The constitution guarantees equality before the law for all.
law enforcement agencies/officials
Kate's word was law in the Brown household.

senses.definition: a particular branch of the law

examples.x: tax/employment law
According to copyright law, the author is the owner of the material.

senses.definition: the study of the law as a subject at university, etc.; the profession of being a lawyer

examples.x: a law student/professor
Jane is studying law.
What made you go into law?
a law firm

senses.definition: used to refer to the police and the legal system

examples.x: Jim is always getting into trouble with the law.
She was well known for her brushes with the law.

senses.definition: the fact that something always happens in the same way in an activity or in nature

examples.x: The usual laws of supply and demand do not seem to apply in this case.
the laws of nature/physics

senses.definition: a scientific rule that somebody has stated to explain a natural process

examples.x: the first law of thermodynamics
Do you remember anything about Ohm's Law?

senses.definition: one of the rules that controls an organization or activity

examples.x: the laws of the Church
The first law of kung fu is to defend yourself.
the laws of cricket

senses.definition: a rule for good behaviour or how you should behave in a particular place or situation

examples.x: He frequently behaved as though moral laws did not exist.
Their world is shaped by their parents' attitudes and the unspoken laws of the street.

senses.definition: the study and treatment of diseases and injuries

examples.x: advances in modern medicine
to study/practise medicine
a professor of medicine
conventional/orthodox medicine
alternative/complementary medicine
Acupuncture has long been a part of traditional Chinese medicine.
a rapidly developing field of medicine
There is a greater emphasis on preventive medicine.

senses.definition: a substance that you take in order to cure an illness, especially a liquid that you drink or swallow catch

examples.x: Did you take your medicine?
Your doctor can prescribe medicine to ease your symptoms.
She gave me a dose of cough medicine.
Chinese herbal medicines
medicine for a chest infection
It's a medicine used to combat diarrhoea.

senses.definition: connected with the earth's atmosphere and its changes, especially in the way they affect the weather

examples.x: meteorological conditions/data

senses.definition: the scientific study of the earth’s atmosphere and its changes, used especially in predicting what the weather will be like
a particular way of doing something

examples.x: Which method is the most effective?
traditional/alternative methods
a scientific method of data analysis
a reliable method of measuring blood pressure
the best method for arriving at an accurate prediction of the costs
Developing new methods to keep insects out of food packages is critical.
to use/employ/apply a method
to devise/propose/adopt a method
He's quite critical of modern teaching methods.

senses.definition: the quality of being well planned and organized

examples.x: There's very little method in his approach.
We have to apply some method to this investigation.

senses.definition: an instrument used in scientific study for making very small things look larger so that you can examine them carefully micro-

examples.x: a microscope slide
The bacteria were then examined under the microscope.
a section of a potato as seen through a microscope

senses.definition: to create a copy or description of an activity, a situation, etc. so that you can study it before dealing with the real thing

examples.x: The program can model a typical home page for you.
We can accurately model the development process.
Air quality planners can model the effects of trees on air pollution.

senses.definition: to represent something, especially in a diagram

examples.x: This finite set of data can be modelled by a growth curve.

senses.definition: to shape clay, etc. in order to make something

examples.x: a statue modelled in bronze
a simple souvenir, modelled in the shape of a horse

senses.definition: to wear clothes in order to show them to people who might want to buy them

examples.x: The wedding gown is being modelled for us by the designer's daughter.
Brad and Cindy are modelling chunky knitwear on the beach.

senses.definition: to work as a model for an artist or in the fashion industry

examples.x: Ralph's been modelling since he was 16.

senses.definition: to set an example of behaviour that you want other people to copy

examples.x: Managers must model behaviour that is open and vulnerable.
Teachers may need to model appropriate discussion behaviours.

senses.definition: a mixture of sand, water, lime and cement used in building for holding bricks and stones together
a heavy gun that fires bombs and shells high into the air; the bombs that are fired by this gun

examples.x: to come under mortar fire/attack

senses.definition: a small hard bowl in which you can crush substances such as seeds and grains to make them into powder with a special object (called a pestle)
a word or statement that means ‘no’; an act of refusing to do something or of denying something

examples.x: She answered in the negative (= said ‘no’).

senses.definition: a bad quality or aspect of a situation

examples.x: Try not to focus on the negative.
The positives outweigh the negatives.

senses.definition: the result of a test or an experiment that shows that a substance or condition is not present

examples.x: The percentage of false negatives generated by the cancer test is of great concern.

senses.definition: a word such as ‘no’, ‘not’, ‘never’, etc.

examples.x: Double negatives, as in ‘I don't want no dinner’, are considered an error in English.

senses.definition: a developed film showing the dark areas of an actual scene as light and the light areas as dark

examples.x: Keep the negatives in case you want more prints later.

senses.definition: the scientific study of the biology of the nervous system, especially in connection with behaviour

examples.x: A big question in neurobiology is how animals, including humans, make decisions.

senses.definition: the idea that an experiment that is done using two groups of people will show the same results for each group
a scientist who studies oceanography
the scientific study of the ocean
the scientific study of diseases
an aspect of somebody’s behaviour that is extreme and unreasonable and that they cannot control
a small heavy tool with a round end used for pressing things to a powder in a special bowl called a mortar
the scientific study of matter and energy and the relationships between them, including the study of forces, heat, light, sound, electricity and the structure of atoms

examples.x: a degree in physics
quantum/theoretical physics
the laws of physics
the physics laboratory/department
a physics professor/teacher
to study the physics of the electron

senses.definition: the scientific study of the normal functions of living things

examples.x: the department of anatomy and physiology

senses.definition: the way in which a particular living thing functions

examples.x: plant physiology
the physiology of the horse

senses.definition: a good or useful quality or aspect

examples.x: What are the positives and negatives of going this route?
I get a lot of positives from my job.
The deal is seen as a positive for both companies.

senses.definition: the result of a test or an experiment that shows that a substance or condition is present

examples.x: The result can be a false positive—indicating a problem where none actually exists.

senses.definition: a developed film showing light and dark areas and colours as they actually were, especially one printed from a negative
the practice of being positive in your attitude and focusing on what is good in a situation

examples.x: We want to send a message of positivity and optimism even in these dark times.

senses.definition: the fact that a particular substance, condition or feature is present

examples.x: the positivity of tumour cells
The state's Covid test positivity rate jumped to 14.5 per cent.

senses.definition: a moral rule or a strong belief that influences your actions principal

examples.x: He has high moral principles.
Stick to your principles and tell him you won't do it.
I refuse to lie about it; it's against my principles.
He doesn't invest in the arms industry on principle.
She refuses to allow her family to help her as a matter of principle.

senses.definition: a law, a rule or a theory that something is based on

examples.x: The same principles apply to both humans and animals.
an important legal principle
‘You learn general principles from studying particular things,’ he asserts.
the basic principles of car maintenance
There are three fundamental principles of teamwork.
to learn the basic/general principles of something
the principles of justice/law
the principles and practice of writing reports
draft principles for the management of shared natural resources
a document setting out principles for resolving the dispute
The principle behind it is very simple.
Discussing all these details will get us nowhere; we must get back to first principles (= the most basic rules).
The court derived a set of principles from this general rule.

senses.definition: a belief that is accepted as a reason for acting or thinking in a particular way

examples.x: The welfare of the child is the guiding principle of the family courts.
They were accused of violating the principles of democracy.
The principle of equality is enshrined in the Constitution.
the application of the principle that men and women should receive equal pay for equal work
The UN declaration sought to establish the principle that everyone is entitled to the same basic rights
the principle that free education should be available for all children
Ethical behaviour entails acting in accordance with established principles of right and wrong

senses.definition: a general or scientific law that explains how something works or why something happens

examples.x: O'Sullivan was among the first chemists to apply scientific principles to brewing beer.
the principle that heat rises
A tidal current turbine is similar in principle to a windmill.

senses.definition: a way of doing something, especially the usual or correct way

examples.x: emergency/safety/disciplinary procedures
Making a complaint is quite a simple procedure.
The school in this case did not follow the correct procedure.
to follow normal/standard/the proper procedure
To ensure high quality, all products go through rigorous testing procedures.
The procedure for logging on to the network involves a password.
Any complaint has to be investigated under our complaints procedure.
All experiments were performed according to standard procedures.

senses.definition: the official or formal order or way of doing something, especially in business, law or politics

examples.x: court/legal/parliamentary procedure

senses.definition: a medical operation

examples.x: a routine surgical procedure
to perform/undergo a procedure

senses.definition: information, documents, etc. that show that something is true

examples.x: conclusive/definitive/scientific proof
The police suspected him of dealing drugs, but they didn't have any proof.
to require/need proof
Can you provide any proof of identity?
Keep the receipt as proof of purchase.
These results are a further proof of his outstanding ability.
There is no proof that the knife belonged to her.
Today's unemployment figures are proof positive the government's economic plan isn't working.
In criminal cases the burden of proof (= requirement to provide proof) is on the prosecution.
plans to lower the standard of proof required to convict people of crimes under the Terrorism Act

senses.definition: the process of testing whether something is true or a fact

examples.x: Is the claim capable of proof?

senses.definition: a way of proving that a statement is true or that what you have calculated is correct
a copy of printed material which is produced so that mistakes can be corrected

examples.x: She was checking the proofs of her latest novel.

senses.definition: a standard used to measure the strength of alcoholic drinks
a system of fixed rules and formal behaviour used at official meetings, usually between governments

examples.x: a breach of protocol
the protocol of diplomatic visits

senses.definition: the first or original version of an agreement, especially a treaty between countries, etc.; an extra part added to an agreement or treaty

examples.x: the first Geneva Protocol
It is set out in a legally binding protocol which forms part of the treaty.
The dates were agreed under a protocol to the climate convention.

senses.definition: a set of rules that control the way data is sent between computers
a plan for performing a scientific experiment or medical treatment
to use facts, evidence, etc. to show that something is true There is clear evidence that

examples.x: They hope this new evidence will prove her innocence.
‘I know you're lying.’ ‘Prove it!’
He felt he needed to prove his point (= show other people that he was right).
Are you just doing this to prove a point?
What are you trying to prove?
I certainly don't have anything to prove—my record speaks for itself.
The prosecution has failed to prove its case.
She continued to prove her worth to the team.
Just give me a chance and I'll prove it to you.
This proves (that) I was right.
She was determined to prove everyone wrong.
In this country, you are innocent until proven guilty.
You've just proved yourself to be a liar.
This just proves what I have been saying for some time.
Can it be proved that he did commit these offences?

senses.definition: if something proves dangerous, expensive, etc. or if it proves to be dangerous, etc., you discover that it is dangerous, etc. over a period of time proves

examples.x: The strategy has proved successful.
The new system has proved popular with our clients.
It was proving extremely difficult to establish the truth.
I have some information that may prove useful.
The opposition proved too strong for him.
The play proved a great success.
Shares in the industry proved a poor investment.
His lack of experience may prove a problem in a crisis.
The promotion proved to be a turning point in her career.
Their fears proved to be groundless.

senses.definition: to show other people how good you are at doing something or that you are capable of doing something

examples.x: He constantly feels he has to prove himself to others.
She wants a chance to prove herself.

senses.definition: to show other people that you are a particular type of person or that you have a particular quality

examples.x: He proved himself determined to succeed.
She proved herself to be a skilful negotiator.

senses.definition: to swell (= become larger or rounder) before being baked because of the action of yeast; to leave bread dough to prove

examples.x: While the dough is proving, crumble the feta and chop the olives.
Prove the dough until it has doubled in size.

senses.definition: a set of theories, beliefs or methods that some people claim are based on scientific fact even though in reality they are not

examples.x: Eugenics was a pseudoscience based on racism.
There's a lot of pseudoscience and misinformation here.

senses.definition: connected with a person’s mind and the way in which it works

examples.x: the psychological development of children
Abuse can lead to both psychological and emotional problems.
Her symptoms are more psychological than physical (= imaginary rather than real).
Victory in the last game gave them a psychological advantage over their opponents.
a psychological novel (= one that examines the minds of the characters)

senses.definition: connected with the study of psychology

examples.x: psychological research
A psychological study of refugee children came up with some worrying results.

senses.definition: a scientist who studies and is trained in psychology

examples.x: to see a psychologist
to go to a psychologist
an educational psychologist
a clinical psychologist (= one who treats people with a mental illness)
I made an appointment with the school psychologist.
a child psychologist
a sports psychologist

senses.definition: the branch of science that investigates the principles of quantum theory to understand the behaviour of particles at the atomic and subatomic level

examples.x: Quantum physics has proven that all matter at the subatomic level exists in wave form.

senses.definition: the 18th letter of the English alphabet

examples.x: ‘Rose’ begins with (an) R/‘R’.

senses.definition: a way of measuring how quickly a virus spreads through a population by calculating the average number of people who get an infection from just one person with the virus (the abbreviation for ‘reproduction number’ or ‘reproductive number’)

examples.x: We are still seeing new infections every day and the R is close to 1.

senses.definition: carbon dating (= a method of calculating the age of very old objects by measuring the amounts of different forms of carbon in them)
to use a method in an experiment, a piece of research, etc. that gives every item an equal chance of being considered; to put things in a random order
a careful study of a subject, especially in order to discover new facts or information about it researches

examples.x: scientific/medical/academic research
They are raising money for cancer research.
to do/conduct/undertake research
I've done some research to find out the cheapest way of travelling there.
He has carried out extensive research into renewable energy sources.
Recent research on deaf children has produced some interesting findings about their speech.
Research on animals has led to some important medical advances.
According to recent research, more people are going to the movies than ever before.
Their latest research project will be funded by the government.
Are you hoping to get a research grant?
a research fellow/assistant/scientist
a research institute/centre/laboratory
The research findings were published in the Journal of Environmental Quality.

senses.definition: to study something carefully and try to discover new facts about it

examples.x: to research a topic/subject
She's in New York researching her new book (= finding facts and information to put in it).
They began researching potential buyers for their product.
The book has been meticulously/exhaustively/thoroughly researched.
They spent days researching in the school library.
We have to research how the product will actually be used.

senses.definition: a thing that is caused or produced because of something else result

examples.x: And did your intervention produce the desired result?
to yield/achieve a result
The company's failure was a direct result of bad management.
This book is the result of 25 years of research.
The end result (= the final one) of her hard work was a place at medical school.
He made one big mistake, and, as a result, lost his job.
She died as a result of her injuries.
The farm was flooded, with the result that the crop was lost.
He decided to get involved, with disastrous results.

senses.definition: the final score or the name of the winner in a sports event, competition, election, etc.

examples.x: the election results
The announcer was reading out the football results.
They will announce the result of the vote tonight.

senses.definition: a victory or a success

examples.x: We badly need to get a result from this match.
This was a great result for us.
He left. Result! (= used when you are happy something has happened)

senses.definition: the mark or grade you get in an exam or in a number of exams

examples.x: Have you had your results yet?
When do you get your exam results?

senses.definition: the information that you get from a scientific test or piece of research formulate/​advance

examples.x: Other research has yielded similar results.
The doctor will explain your blood test results.
a positive/negative test result
the results of a study
The results of our experiment indicate that environmental factors play a part.
The results obtained were compared with previous results.

senses.definition: the information that you get from a computer search

examples.x: My search produced several thousand results.
The user can control how the search results are displayed.
the first page of search results

senses.definition: things that are achieved successfully

examples.x: The project is beginning to show results.
a coach who knows how to get results from his players
For best results, defrost fully before use.

senses.definition: the amount of profit or loss made by a business over a particular period of time

examples.x: Companies are required by law to report their financial results on a quarterly basis.
The company will publish its interim results (= before the final results are known) on Monday.
The corporation is expected to announce improved results for the last quarter.

senses.definition: a way of measuring how quickly a virus spreads through a population by calculating the average number of people who get an infection from just one person with the virus (the abbreviation for ‘reproduction number’ or ‘reproductive number’)

examples.x: Scientists will be watching the R number very closely to ensure it doesn't rise above 1.0.

senses.definition: a number of people or things taken from a larger group and used in tests to provide information about the group

examples.x: The interviews were given to a random sample of students.
The survey covers a representative sample of schools.
a sample survey
The current study has a larger sample size than earlier studies.
We studied a large population sample.

senses.definition: a small amount of a substance taken from a larger amount and tested in order to obtain information about the substance formulate/​advance

examples.x: a blood/urine/tissue/DNA sample
Samples of the water contained pesticide.
A small sample of blood must be tested by a doctor.
to collect/obtain/take a sample
We analyzed samples from more than a dozen common tree species.
Her sample contained traces of the banned steroid.

senses.definition: a small amount or example of something that can be looked at or tried to see what it is like

examples.x: ‘I'd like to see a sample of your work,’ said the manager.
a free sample of shampoo
Would you like a sample of the fabric to take home?
We looked at sample books to choose the fabric.

senses.definition: a piece of recorded music or sound that is used in a new piece of music

examples.x: ‘Candy’ includes a swirling sample from a Walker Brothers song.

senses.definition: knowledge about the structure and behaviour of the natural and physical world, based on facts that you can prove, for example by experiments

examples.x: new developments in science and technology
the advance of modern science
the laws of science

senses.definition: the study of science

examples.x: science students/teachers/classes
She is trying to encourage more young people to study science.

senses.definition: a particular branch of science

examples.x: medical/environmental science
the biological sciences
to study one of the sciences
He was a pioneer in the science of genetics.

senses.definition: a system for organizing the knowledge about a particular subject, especially one that deals with aspects of human behaviour or society

examples.x: a science of international politics

senses.definition: involving science; connected with science formulate/​advance

examples.x: a scientific discovery/theory/fact
scientific research/evidence/knowledge/methods
sites of scientific interest
a scientific journal/paper/study
The consensus among the scientific community (= people who work in science) is that the average world surface temperature is 1.1°F higher than 100 years ago.

senses.definition: careful and logical

examples.x: He took a very scientific approach to management.
We need to be more scientific about this problem.

senses.definition: a person who studies or is an expert in one or more of the natural sciences (= for example, physics, chemistry or biology)

examples.x: a research scientist
nuclear/climate scientists
scientists and engineers
the cartoon figure of the mad scientist working in his laboratory
Scientists believe there is ice a few inches below the surface of Mars.

senses.definition: to give details about an aspect of your life, typically relating to your physical or mental condition

examples.x: Participants in the survey had to self-report their health status.
For this study, patients self-reported whether or not they did regular exercise.
61% of respondents self-reported that they were likely to vote in the forthcoming elections.

senses.definition: details that you provide about an aspect of your life, typically relating to your physical or mental condition

examples.x: Participants completed self-report questionnaires measuring anxiety and depression.

senses.definition: one page of an electronic presentation, that may contain text and images, that is usually viewed on a computer screen or projected onto a larger screen

examples.x: Here's a slide showing target markets.
I'm still working on the slides for my presentation.
Limit the amount of text on each slide.
The numbers mentioned in the slide are based on theoretical scenarios.
a slide presentation

senses.definition: a long, smooth movement on ice or a smooth surface

examples.x: Her car went into a slide.
a front wheel slide

senses.definition: a change to a lower or worse condition

examples.x: a downward slide in the price of oil
the team’s slide down the table
talks to prevent a slide into civil war
The economy is on the slide (= getting worse).
a stock market slide

senses.definition: a structure with a steep slope that children use for sliding down

examples.x: to go down the slide

senses.definition: a sudden fall of a large amount of rock or earth down a hill

examples.x: I was afraid of starting a slide of loose stones.

senses.definition: a small piece of film held in a frame that can be shown on a screen when you shine a light through it

examples.x: a talk with colour slides

senses.definition: a small piece of glass that something is placed on so that it can be looked at under a microscope
a part of a musical instrument or other device that slides backwards and forwards
a small attractive piece of metal or plastic used by women for holding their hair in place
the study of soil, for example the study of its structure or characteristics
a collection of information shown in numbers

examples.x: Analysis of crime statistics showed high levels of violent crime within the area.
Statistics show that far more people are able to ride a bicycle than can drive a car.
These statistics are misleading.
According to official statistics, the disease killed over 500 people.
He should read some of the statistics on economic growth.

senses.definition: the science of collecting and analysing statistics

examples.x: There is a compulsory course in statistics.

senses.definition: a piece of information shown in numbers

examples.x: An important statistic is that 94 per cent of crime relates to property.
As with every statistic, there are trends behind the numbers.
I felt I was no longer being treated as a person but as a statistic.

senses.definition: a collection of information shown in numbers

examples.x: The match stats show that there were 16 instances of players being offside.

senses.definition: the science of collecting and analysing statistics
the activity of learning or gaining knowledge, either from books or by examining things in the world

examples.x: a room set aside for private study
academic/literary/scientific study
It is important to develop good study skills.
Physiology is the study of how living things work.

senses.definition: a particular person’s learning activities, for example at a college or university

examples.x: to continue your studies
Many undertake further studies after college.

senses.definition: used in the names of some academic subjects

examples.x: business/media/American studies

senses.definition: a piece of research that examines a subject or question in detail formulate/​advance

examples.x: to conduct/undertake a study
Research studies carried out in Italy confirmed the theory.
He has recently done a study on the effects of traffic and aircraft noise.
a detailed study of how animals adapt to their environment
scientific studies of fishing grounds and methods of fishing
This study shows/finds/suggests that…
the purpose/aim of a study
the results/findings of a study
the methods used in the present study
in previous/earlier studies
According to a recent study published in the Journal of Sleep Research…

senses.definition: an academic book or article on a particular topic

examples.x: a study of Jane Austen's novels
Shakespeare is the subject of a new study by Anthony Bryan.

senses.definition: the act of considering or examining something in detail

examples.x: These proposals deserve careful study.
the biochemical process under study

senses.definition: a room, especially in somebody’s home, used for reading and writing

examples.x: She crossed the hallway and opened the door to her private study.

senses.definition: a drawing or painting of something, especially one done for practice or before doing a larger picture

examples.x: a study of Chartres Cathedral
a nude study

senses.definition: the act of showing or describing somebody/something in literature or another art form, especially a character or an aspect of behaviour

examples.x: The novel is a character study of a city and its people.

senses.definition: a piece of music designed to give a player practice in technical skills
a perfect example of something

examples.x: His face was a study in concentration.

senses.definition: to spend time learning about a subject by reading, going to college, etc. acquire/​get/​lack

examples.x: He sat up very late that night, studying.
How long have you been studying English?
Don't disturb Jane, she's studying for her exams.
My brother studied photography at the Royal College of Art.
She studied at New College, Oxford.
a composer who studied music under Nadia Boulanger (= was taught music by Nadia Boulanger)
He studied under Wagner in Vienna.
Nina is studying to be an architect.
He is studying to teach children with special needs.

senses.definition: to watch or to look at somebody/something carefully in order to find out something

examples.x: Scientists are studying photographs of the planet for signs of life.
He studied her face thoughtfully.
Fran was studying the menu.
She picked up the letter and studied it carefully.

senses.definition: to examine something carefully in order to understand it examine

examples.x: We will study the report carefully before making a decision.
The group will study how the region coped with the loss of thousands of jobs.
They are studying what happens to people who unexpectedly win a lot of money.

senses.definition: a thing or person that is being discussed, described or dealt with

examples.x: Walker's work has been the subject of much debate.
a subject of discussion/conversation
Nelson Mandela is the subject of a new biography.
The incident is currently the subject of a police investigation.
books on many different subjects
I have nothing more to say on the subject.
a magazine article on the subject of space travel
How did we get onto the subject of marriage?
I wish you'd change the subject (= talk about something else).
We seem to have got off the subject we're meant to be discussing.
a subject for debate/discussion
The university runs a wide range of research programmes in different subject areas.

senses.definition: an area of knowledge studied in a school, college, etc.

examples.x: Biology is my favourite subject.
