Which subjects are you studying?
The college offers a wide range of subjects.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is the main feature of a picture or photograph, or that a work of art is based on

examples.x: Focus the camera on the subject.
Classical landscapes were a popular subject with many 18th century painters.

senses.definition: a person or thing being used to study something, especially in an experiment

examples.x: We need male subjects between the ages of 18 and 25 for the experiment.

senses.definition: a noun, noun phrase or pronoun representing the person or thing that performs the action of the verb (I in I sat down.), about which something is stated (the house in the house is very old) or, in a passive sentence, that is affected by the action of the verb (the tree in the tree was blown down in the storm)
a person who belongs to a particular country, especially one with a king or queen

examples.x: a British subject
The prince had to tax his subjects heavily to raise money for the war.

senses.definition: an investigation of the opinions, behaviour, etc. of a particular group of people, which is usually done by asking them questions

examples.x: A recent survey showed 75 per cent of those questioned were in favour of the plan.
The survey revealed/found that…
to conduct/carry out/do/complete a survey
According to the survey, many young adults have experimented with drugs of some kind.
Another national survey conducted last year found the same result.
Roughly half of survey respondents express strong interest in additional education.
The results of the survey come as no surprise to us.

senses.definition: the act of examining and recording the measurements, features, etc. of an area of land in order to make a map or plan of it

examples.x: an aerial survey (= made by taking photographs from a plane, drone, etc.)
A geological survey revealed the presence of oil beneath the ground.

senses.definition: an examination of the condition of a house, etc., usually done for somebody who is thinking of buying it

examples.x: a detailed structural survey

senses.definition: a general study, view or description of something

examples.x: a comprehensive survey of modern music
a historical survey of children's clothing

senses.definition: a person, an object, an event, etc. that represents a more general quality or situation cymbal

examples.x: The vase is decorated with religious symbols.
The new school stands as a symbol of hope for a better future.
Mandela became a symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle.

senses.definition: a sign, number, letter, etc. that has a fixed meaning, especially in science, mathematics and music

examples.x: the mathematical symbol for infinity
Hotels that display this symbol offer activities for children.

senses.definition: a plastic or glass tube with a long hollow needle that is used for putting drugs, etc. into a person’s body or for taking a small amount of blood from a person

examples.x: a beach scattered with used syringes

senses.definition: a plastic or glass tube with a rubber part at the end, used for taking liquid in and then pushing it out
scientific knowledge used in practical ways in industry, for example in designing new machines

examples.x: science and technology
advances in communications technology
advanced/modern technology
to develop and use new technologies
small businesses that are involved with emerging technologies
the use of the latest digital technology to create a virtual world
This technology enables computers to read handwriting.

senses.definition: machines or equipment designed using technology

examples.x: The scheme provides access to advanced computer technology in the classroom.
The company has invested in the latest technology.
a wireless technology company
the technology sector/industry

senses.definition: a piece of equipment like a tube in shape, containing lenses, that you look through to make objects that are far away appear larger and nearer

examples.x: to look at the stars through a telescope

senses.definition: an examination of somebody’s knowledge or ability, consisting of questions for them to answer or activities for them to perform acquire/​get/​lack

examples.x: an IQ test
a test on irregular verbs
Students take standardized tests in English and maths.
to do a test
to pass/fail a test
a good mark in the test
a good score on the test

senses.definition: a medical examination to discover what is wrong with you or to check the condition of your health

examples.x: The hospital is doing some tests.
We'll need to perform a series of tests.
screening tests for cancer
Three athletes were sent home after failing drugs tests.
The pregnancy test was positive.
negative/positive test results

senses.definition: an experiment to discover whether or how well something works, or to find out more information about it

examples.x: the results of laboratory tests
to conduct a nuclear test
Tests have shown high levels of pollutants in the water.
I'll run a diagnostic test to determine why the server keeps crashing.

senses.definition: a situation or an event that shows how good, strong, etc. somebody/something is

examples.x: The local elections will be a good test of the government's popularity.
He saw their separation as a test of the strength of their love.

senses.definition: a cricket or rugby match played between the teams of two different countries, usually as part of a series of matches on a tour

examples.x: They played well in the first Test against South Africa.
He will be first choice for the opening test against the All Blacks.

senses.definition: to find out how much somebody knows, or what they can do by asking them questions or giving them activities to perform

examples.x: Students will be tested at the end of each module.
Children are tested on core subjects at age 11.
We test all students in English and maths.
Applicants' skills, ability and knowledge are tested before job offers are made.
We test your English before deciding which class to put you in.

senses.definition: to perform well/badly in a test of knowledge or ability

examples.x: students who tested well in reading
There are people who test well and people who don’t.

senses.definition: to examine the blood, a part of the body, etc. to find out what is wrong with a person, or to check the condition of their health

examples.x: to test somebody’s eyesight/hearing
The doctor tested him for hepatitis.

senses.definition: to produce a particular result in a medical test

examples.x: She tested negative for HIV.
Two athletes tested positive for steroids.

senses.definition: to use or try a machine, substance, idea, etc. to find out how well it works or to find out more information about it

examples.x: Test your brakes regularly.
The new system has been rigorously tested.
Our beauty products are not tested on animals.
The chef uses his family to test out new ideas for the restaurant menu.
They opened a single store in Europe to test out the market.
The software has been tested for viruses.
The water is regularly tested for purity.
Researchers are now testing the hypothesis against available data.

senses.definition: (of a machine or product) to perform well/badly in a test of how well it works

examples.x: The ad had tested badly with consumers.

senses.definition: to be difficult and therefore need all your strength, ability, etc.

examples.x: The long climb tested our fitness and stamina.

senses.definition: a small glass tube, closed at one end, that is used in scientific experiments Test tube
connected with the ideas and principles on which a particular subject is based, rather than with practice and experiment

examples.x: a theoretical approach
theoretical physics
The first year provides students with a sound theoretical basis for later study.

senses.definition: that could possibly exist, happen or be true, although this is unlikely

examples.x: It's a theoretical possibility.

senses.definition: a formal set of ideas that is intended to explain why something happens or exists formulate/​advance

examples.x: the theory of evolution/relativity
scientific/economic theory
The theories were tested on a sample of the population.
He developed a new theory about the cause of stomach ulcers.
theories on human behaviour
She has written a book explaining the theory behind her art.
According to the theory of relativity, nothing can travel faster than light.

senses.definition: the principles on which a particular subject is based

examples.x: the theory and practice of language teaching
This is your chance to put theory into practice .
literary theory

senses.definition: an opinion or idea that somebody believes is true but that is not proved

examples.x: Theories abound (= people have lots of different ideas) about what happened.
Here's my theory on how the story's going to end.
I don't subscribe to the theory that all Hollywood audiences want a happy ending.
Police are working on the theory that the murderer was known to the family.

senses.definition: a long piece of writing completed by a student as part of a university degree, based on their own research

examples.x: Students must submit a thesis on an agreed subject within four years.

senses.definition: a statement or an opinion that is discussed in a logical way and presented with evidence in order to prove that it is true formulate/​advance

examples.x: The basic thesis of the book is fairly simple.
These latest findings support the thesis that sexuality is determined by nature rather than choice.

senses.definition: a mental assessment of the possible effects or results of a theory

examples.x: Einstein is known for his thought experiments, which often start with one question: ‘What if …?’

senses.definition: a formal examination of evidence in court by a judge and often a jury, to decide if somebody accused of a crime is guilty or not break/​violate/​obey/​uphold

examples.x: a murder/criminal trial
He's on trial for murder.
She will stand trial/go on trial for fraud.
He should have been arrested and put on trial.
He was facing trial on a murder charge.
The men were arrested but not brought to trial.
She is awaiting trial on corruption charges.
He did not receive a fair trial.
the right to trial by jury
She was detained without trial.
a trial judge/lawyer/court
She became a key witness in the trial.
They will lose their right to a jury trial.

senses.definition: the process of testing the ability, quality or performance of somebody/something, especially before you make a final decision about them formulate/​advance

examples.x: a field/randomized/controlled trial
Australia and the US have conducted joint trials of the drone.
She agreed to employ me for a trial period.
We had the machine on trial for a week.
The system was introduced on a trial basis for one month.
a trial separation (= of a couple whose marriage is in difficulties)
a trial of strength (= a contest to see who is stronger)

senses.definition: a competition or series of tests to find the best players for a sports team or an important event

examples.x: Olympic trials

senses.definition: an event at which animals compete or perform

examples.x: horse trials

senses.definition: an experience or a person that causes difficulties for somebody

examples.x: the trials and tribulations of married life
She was a sore trial to her family at times.
My first day at work was a trial by fire.

senses.definition: to check that something is true or accurate

examples.x: We have no way of verifying his story.
Please verify that there is sufficient memory available before loading the program.
Please verify that your password was entered correctly.
I'll leave you to verify whether these claims are true.

senses.definition: to show or say that something is true or accurate

examples.x: Her version of events was verified by neighbours.
Several witnesses verified his story.

senses.definition: the practice of doing experiments on live animals for medical or scientific research
a balloon that carries instruments into the atmosphere to measure weather conditions
the scientific study of animals and their behaviour -logy
